newsitem.title: USA: Medic slammed after earnings warning.
newsitem.headline: Medic slammed after earnings warning.

text.p: Investors dumped shares of Medic Computer System Inc after the developer of physician practice management systems said it expects its first quarter earnings and revenues to fall below analysts' estimates.
Medic Computer dropped 13-7/8 to 14-1/8 and was one of the most active Nasdaq issues.

"This is an overreaction. The forecast is clearly disappointing but the company fundamentals remain strong," said Jason Rosenbluth. "The market is relentless with companies that miss their earnings targets."
Medic said earlier on Monday that it expects to report first-quarter share earnings of $0.14 to $0.18, below analysts' expectations of about $0.27 per share and the year ago's $0.21 per share.

The company also projected that first-quarter revenues will be below consensus estimates, with total net revenues ranging from $47 million to $49 million. The expected first quarter revenues compared with total net revenues of $43.37 million a year ago, after restatement for the acquisition of CompuSystems in May 1996 accounted for as a pooling of interests.
Medic attributed the drop in revenues to lower-than-expected systems sales, primarily in January and February, and to the longer cycle for implementation of the larger MEDIC Vision systems.
Medic said bookings in March have improved and are expected to include significant MEDIC Vision systems.
Analysts said Medic's near-term results will be dampened by the transition to its new product line, but long-term prospects remain strong.
But Medic's sharp stock decline on Monday should not spook holders of other health care information companies since the sector's long-term outlook is rosy, analysts said.
